arm_group.description: 0.1% vitamin A palmitate; Sinqi, Shenyang, China

brief_summary.textblock:
Most of the patients under long application of anti-glaucoma eyedrops endure severe ocular
      surface irritation, which interrupt their quality of life a lot. Lots of studies aimed to
      search for new drugs for therapy. The investigators hypothesized that the artificial tears
      containing vitamin A or carbomer may be a great substitute. Both of the two drugs were in
      common use and had already been tested in animals.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Vitamin A and Carbomer in Comforting the Ocular Surface Irritations of Glaucoma Patients

intervention.description: use one drop in the eye
use one drop in the eye

primary_outcome.measure: change of the density of conjunctival goblet cells
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from Baseline in goblet cell density at 6 months

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: tear film parameters changes in patients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline in TBUT and Schirmer test at 6 months

secondary_outcome.measure: changes of ocular irritation in patients
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline in OSDI scores at 6 months

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
